awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  M-ary Distributed Detection in Wireless Sensor Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This research focuses on integrating M-ary distributed detection and 
communications, and makes a significant impact on the theory and 
practice of wireless sensor networks (WSNs) and cognitive radio networks 
(CRNs). In particular, the following four problems are tackled.

(1) M-ary distributed detection: The PI develops fusion rules and local 
decision rules for M-ary distributed detection systems with different 
wireless channel models, and studies how the erroneous channels 
fundamentally limit the performance of these systems. Furthermore, two 
composite M-ary distributed detection problems that have applications in 
WSNs and CRNs are investigated: joint detection and localization of 
multiple acoustic sources and spectrum sensing in a multi-channel 
system. (2) Sequential methods for wireless distributed detection 
systems: Striving to gain a profound understanding of the tradeoffs 
between static and sequential distributed detection in wireless 
networks, the PI designs two sequential distributed detection systems 
with i) sequential tests only at the sensors and ii) sequential test 
only at the fusion center, and studies how the detection reliability and 
delay of static and sequential detection systems are affected by the 
adopted wireless channel model. (3) Impact of imperfect channel state 
information on the performance of wireless distributed detection 
systems: The PI studies the effects of channel estimation errors on the 
designs of static and sequential distributed detection systems and 
investigates how these errors further limit the system detection 
performance. (4) Cooperation in wireless distributed detection systems: 
For both static and sequential distributed detection systems cooperative 
schemes are developed, based on local information passing among 
neighboring nodes, and conditions under which cooperation provides gain, 
in terms of both detection reliability and delay, are explored and the 
relationships between the cooperative gain and different channel models 
are sought.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The wireless sensor network technology has the potential to transform many aspects of our civilian lives. This potential, coupled with its low cost and flexibility in deployment, has lead to visions for a plethora of applications such as smart cities and connected communities, healthcare monitoring, environmental monitoring, and surveillance. A wireless sensor network can be viewed as a distributed information processing system, in which low power sensors collect signals, process these signals to perform reliable inference tasks, and transmit the information to a destination over wireless communication channels. From a signal processing perspective, a major design challenge in such distributed information processing systems is to architect optimal and near-optimal distributed detection designs that are resilient to the wireless channel impairments, under strict transmission constraints (in terms of transmit power and bandwidth). This project develops optimal and near-optimal channel-aware distributed detection designs, where the developed designs integrate signal processing and communication blocks, via exploiting communication channel state information. The key outcomes of this project follow.

 (1) We have studied the effect of channel estimation error on sensor selection and the asymptotic decay in error probability exponent, and established how this effect varies as digital transmission scheme and communication channel model change. Our contributions are the first works on understanding the effect of channel estimation error on the design and performance of channel-aware distributed detection systems. Also, we have developed novel cooperative schemes that allow limited local information exchange among sensors to improve the system performance, and studied the tradeoffs between communication overhead (due to local information exchange) and system performance.

 (2) For linear fusion rules, we have characterized how the statistical correlation across sensors' data affects the best achievable performance of channel-aware distributed detection systems. We have shown that, via adapting transmit power to the correlation value, multiple-channel-access scheme, and channel state information, we can improve the system performance up to 60%. For a wireless sensor network tasked with solving an M-ary hypothesis testing problem, we have developed near-optimal channel-aware distributed detection designs, that take into account channel estimation error and receiver type (coherent and non-coherent receivers).

 (3) We have studied the connections between the optimal channel-aware distributed detection design, communication network topology, and communication channel models. We have shown that, via jointly adapting the decision and fusion rules to communication network topology and channel state information, we can increase the overall detection reliability of the system up to 50%.

(4) Considering a wireless sensor network, where sensors are energy harvesters with finite capacity batteries, we have developed near-optimal channel-aware distributed detection designs, that enable adaptive transmit power according to the battery state and channel state information, such that the long-term detection performance of the system is guaranteed. Our findings have important practical implications on designing self-sustainable wireless sensor networks.

The research activities supported by this project have impacts on the theory and practice of wireless sensor network technologies. We have disseminated our key findings and generated knowledge to research communities of interest, via publishing in peer-reviewed journals and refereed IEEE conference proceedings. The gained knowledge throughout this project enabled us to find new and exciting research opportunities in other disciplines, including advanced brain signal processing and mathematical modeling of human auditory system.

Furthermore, this project has facilitated training the next generation of scientists and engineers that have joined and will join STEM workforce. During the course of this project, 8 graduate (7 PhD and 1 MS) and 1 undergraduate students made significant scientific contributions toward achieving the goals of this project. Five PhD students (1 female) have already completed their PhD studies and joined STEM workforce. The remaining two individuals (1 female) are on their paths to earn their PhD degrees.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/24/2020
Modified by: Azadeh Vosoughi
